Any extra props you add to \u003ccode\u003e\u0026lt;InView\u0026gt;\u003c/code\u003e will be\npassed to the HTML element, allowing you set the \u003ccode\u003eclassName\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003estyle\u003c/code\u003e, etc.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"import { InView } from 'react-intersection-observer';\n\nconst Component = () =\u0026gt; (\n  \u0026lt;InView as=\u0026quot;div\u0026quot; onChange={(inView, entry) =\u0026gt; console.log('Inview:', inView)}\u0026gt;\n    \u0026lt;h2\u0026gt;Plain children are always rendered. \u003ccode\u003euseInView\u003c/code\u003e hook or as props on the\n\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ccode\u003e\u0026lt;InView /\u0026gt;\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e component.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable\u003e\n\u003cthead\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003cth\u003eName\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003cth\u003eType\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003cth\u003eDefault\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003cth\u003eDescription\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/thead\u003e\n\u003ctbody\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eroot\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003eElement\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003edocument\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eThe Intersection Observer interface's read-only root property identifies the Element or Document whose bounds are treated as the bounding box of the viewport for the element which is the observer's target. If the root is \u003ccode\u003enull\u003c/code\u003e, then the bounds of the actual document viewport are used.\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003cstrong\u003erootMargin\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003estring\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003e'0px'\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eMargin around the root. Can have values similar to the CSS margin property, e.g. \u003ccode\u003e\"10px 20px 30px 40px\"\u003c/code\u003e (top, right, bottom, left).\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ethreshold\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003enumber\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003enumber[]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003e0\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eNumber between \u003ccode\u003e0\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003e1\u003c/code\u003e indicating the percentage that should be visible before triggering. Can also be an array of numbers, to create multiple trigger points.\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eonChange\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003e(inView, entry) =\u0026gt; void\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003eundefined\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eCall this function whenever the in view state changes. It will receive the \u003ccode\u003einView\u003c/code\u003e boolean, alongside the current \u003ccode\u003eIntersectionObserverEntry\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003cstrong\u003etrackVisibility\u003c/strong\u003e 🧪\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003eboolean\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003efalse\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eA boolean indicating whether this Intersection Observer will track visibility changes on the target.\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003cstrong\u003edelay\u003c/strong\u003e 🧪\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003enumber\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003eundefined\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eA number indicating the minimum delay in milliseconds between notifications from this observer for a given target. This must be set to at least \u003ccode\u003e100\u003c/code\u003e if \u003ccode\u003etrackVisibility\u003c/code\u003e is \u003ccode\u003etrue\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eskip\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003eboolean\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003efalse\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eSkip creating the IntersectionObserver. You can use this to enable and disable the observer as needed. If \u003ccode\u003eskip\u003c/code\u003e is set while \u003ccode\u003einView\u003c/code\u003e, the current state will still be kept.\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003cstrong\u003etriggerOnce\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003eboolean\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003efalse\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eOnly trigger the observer once.\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003cstrong\u003einitialInView\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003eboolean\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003efalse\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eSet the initial value of the \u003ccode\u003einView\u003c/code\u003e boolean. This can be used if you expect the element to be in the viewport to start with, and you want to trigger something when it leaves.\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003cstrong\u003efallbackInView\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003eboolean\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003eundefined\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eIf the \u003ccode\u003eIntersectionObserver\u003c/code\u003e API isn't available in the client, the default behavior is to throw an Error. You can set a specific fallback behavior, and the \u003ccode\u003einView\u003c/code\u003e value will be set to this instead of failing. To set a global default, you can set it with the \u003ccode\u003edefaultFallbackInView()\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/tbody\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eInView Props\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-inview-props\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: InView Props\" href=\"#inview-props\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ccode\u003e\u0026lt;InView /\u0026gt;\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e component also accepts the following props:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable\u003e\n\u003cthead\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003cth\u003eName\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003cth\u003eType\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003cth\u003eDefault\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003cth\u003eDescription\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/thead\u003e\n\u003ctbody\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eas\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003eIntrinsicElement\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003e'div'\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eRender the wrapping element as this element. Defaults to \u003ccode\u003ediv\u003c/code\u003e. If you want to use a custom component, please use the \u003ccode\u003euseInView\u003c/code\u003e hook or a render prop instead to manage the reference explictly.\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003cstrong\u003echildren\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003e({ref, inView, entry}) =\u0026gt; ReactNode\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003eReactNode\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003eundefined\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eChildren expects a function that receives an object containing the \u003ccode\u003einView\u003c/code\u003e boolean and a \u003ccode\u003eref\u003c/code\u003e that should be assigned to the element root. Alternatively pass a plain child, to have the \u003ccode\u003e\u0026lt;InView /\u0026gt;\u003c/code\u003e deal with the wrapping element. You will also get the \u003ccode\u003eIntersectionObserverEntry\u003c/code\u003e as \u003ccode\u003eentry\u003c/code\u003e, giving you more details.\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/tbody\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eIntersection Observer v2 🧪\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-intersection-observer-v2-\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Intersection Observer v2 🧪\" href=\"#intersection-observer-v2-\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe new\n\u003ca href=\"https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2019/02/intersectionobserver-v2\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ev2 implementation of IntersectionObserver\u003c/a\u003e\nextends the original API, so you can track if the element is covered by another\nelement or has filters applied to it. 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn order to write meaningful tests, the \u003ccode\u003eIntersectionObserver\u003c/code\u003e needs to be\nmocked. You can use the included \u003ccode\u003ereact-intersection-observer/test-utils\u003c/code\u003e to\nhelp with this. It mocks the \u003ccode\u003eIntersectionObserver\u003c/code\u003e, and includes a few methods\nto assist with faking the \u003ccode\u003einView\u003c/code\u003e state. When setting the \u003ccode\u003eisIntersecting\u003c/code\u003e\nvalue you can pass either a \u003ccode\u003eboolean\u003c/code\u003e value or a threshold between 0 and 1. It\nwill emulate the real IntersectionObserver, allowing you to validate that your\ncomponents are behaving as expected.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable\u003e\n\u003cthead\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003cth\u003eMethod\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003cth\u003eDescription\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/thead\u003e\n\u003ctbody\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003emockAllIsIntersecting(isIntersecting)\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eSet \u003ccode\u003eisIntersecting\u003c/code\u003e on all current Intersection Observer instances. The value of \u003ccode\u003eisIntersecting\u003c/code\u003e should be either a \u003ccode\u003eboolean\u003c/code\u003e or a threshold between 0 and 1.\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003emockIsIntersecting(element, isIntersecting)\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eSet \u003ccode\u003eisIntersecting\u003c/code\u003e for the Intersection Observer of a specific \u003ccode\u003eelement\u003c/code\u003e. The value of \u003ccode\u003eisIntersecting\u003c/code\u003e should be either a \u003ccode\u003eboolean\u003c/code\u003e or a threshold between 0 and 1.\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003eintersectionMockInstance(element)\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eCall the \u003ccode\u003eintersectionMockInstance\u003c/code\u003e method with an element, to get the (mocked) \u003ccode\u003eIntersectionObserver\u003c/code\u003e instance. You can use this to spy on the \u003ccode\u003eobserve\u003c/code\u003e and\u003ccode\u003eunobserve\u003c/code\u003e methods.\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003esetupIntersectionMocking(mockFn)\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eMock the \u003ccode\u003eIntersectionObserver\u003c/code\u003e, so we can interact with them in tests - Should be called in \u003ccode\u003ebeforeEach\u003c/code\u003e. (\u003cstrong\u003eDone automatically in Jest environment\u003c/strong\u003e)\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003eresetIntersectionMocking()\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eReset the mocks on \u003ccode\u003eIntersectionObserver\u003c/code\u003e - Should be called in \u003ccode\u003eafterEach\u003c/code\u003e. (\u003cstrong\u003eDone automatically in Jest environment\u003c/strong\u003e)\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/tbody\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" data-testid=\u0026quot;wrapper\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\n      {inView.toString()}\n    \u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\n  );\n};\n\ntest('should create a hook inView', () =\u0026gt; {\n screen.getByText('true');\n});\n\ntest('should create a hook inView with threshold', () =\u0026gt; {\n  render(\u0026lt;HookComponent options={{ threshold: 0.3 }}/\u0026gt;);\n\n screen.getByText('true');\n});\n\ntest('should mock intersecing on specific hook', () =\u0026gt; {\n  render(\u0026lt;HookComponent/\u0026gt;);\n  const wrapper = screen.getByTestId('wrapper');\n\n or as props on the<strong><code><InView /></code></strong> component.</p><table><thead><tr><th>Name</th><th>Type</th><th>Default</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>root</strong></td><td><code>Element</code></td><td><code>document</code></td><td>The Intersection Observer interface's read-only root property identifies the Element or Document whose bounds are treated as the bounding box of the viewport for the element which is the observer's target. If the root is <code>null</code>, then the bounds of the actual document viewport are used.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>rootMargin</strong></td><td><code>string</code></td><td><code>'0px'</code></td><td>Margin around the root. Can have values similar to the CSS margin property, e.g. <code>"10px 20px 30px 40px"</code> (top, right, bottom, left).</td></tr><tr><td><strong>threshold</strong></td><td><code>number</code> or <code>number[]</code></td><td><code>0</code></td><td>Number between <code>0</code> and <code>1</code> indicating the percentage that should be visible before triggering. Can also be an array of numbers, to create multiple trigger points.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>onChange</strong></td><td><code>(inView, entry) => void</code></td><td><code>undefined</code></td><td>Call this function whenever the in view state changes. It will receive the <code>inView</code> boolean, alongside the current <code>IntersectionObserverEntry</code>.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>trackVisibility</strong> 🧪</td><td><code>boolean</code></td><td><code>false</code></td><td>A boolean indicating whether this Intersection Observer will track visibility changes on the target.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>delay</strong> 🧪</td><td><code>number</code></td><td><code>undefined</code></td><td>A number indicating the minimum delay in milliseconds between notifications from this observer for a given target. This must be set to at least <code>100</code> if <code>trackVisibility</code> is <code>true</code>.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>skip</strong></td><td><code>boolean</code></td><td><code>false</code></td><td>Skip creating the IntersectionObserver. You can use this to enable and disable the observer as needed. If <code>skip</code> is set while <code>inView</code>, the current state will still be kept.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>triggerOnce</strong></td><td><code>boolean</code></td><td><code>false</code></td><td>Only trigger the observer once.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>initialInView</strong></td><td><code>boolean</code></td><td><code>false</code></td><td>Set the initial value of the <code>inView</code> boolean. This can be used if you expect the element to be in the viewport to start with, and you want to trigger something when it leaves.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>fallbackInView</strong></td><td><code>boolean</code></td><td><code>undefined</code></td><td>If the <code>IntersectionObserver</code> API isn't available in the client, the default behavior is to throw an Error. You can set a specific fallback behavior, and the <code>inView</code> value will be set to this instead of failing. To set a global default, you can set it with the <code>defaultFallbackInView()</code></td></tr></tbody></table><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">InView Props</h3><a id="user-content-inview-props" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: InView Props" href="#inview-props"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The <strong><code><InView /></code></strong> component also accepts the following props:</p><table><thead><tr><th>Name</th><th>Type</th><th>Default</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>as</strong></td><td><code>IntrinsicElement</code></td><td><code>'div'</code></td><td>Render the wrapping element as this element. Defaults to <code>div</code>. If you want to use a custom component, please use the <code>useInView</code> hook or a render prop instead to manage the reference explictly.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>children</strong></td><td><code>({ref, inView, entry}) => ReactNode</code> or <code>ReactNode</code></td><td><code>undefined</code></td><td>Children expects a function that receives an object containing the <code>inView</code> boolean and a <code>ref</code> that should be assigned to the element root. Alternatively pass a plain child, to have the <code><InView /></code> deal with the wrapping element. You will also get the <code>IntersectionObserverEntry</code> as <code>entry</code>, giving you more details.</td></tr></tbody></table><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Intersection Observer v2 🧪</h3><a id="user-content-intersection-observer-v2-" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Intersection Observer v2 🧪" href="#intersection-observer-v2-"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The new<a href="https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2019/02/intersectionobserver-v2" rel="nofollow">v2 implementation of IntersectionObserver</a>extends the original API, so you can track if the element is covered by anotherelement or has filters applied to it. Useful for blocking clickjacking attemptsor tracking ad exposure.</p><p dir="auto">To use it, you'll need to add the new <code>trackVisibility</code> and <code>delay</code> options.When you get the <code>entry</code> back, you can then monitor if <code>isVisible</code> is <code>true</code>.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="const TrackVisible = () => {  const { ref, entry } = useInView({ trackVisibility: true, delay: 100 });  return <div ref={ref}>{entry?.isVisible}</div>;};"><pre><span class="pl-k">const</span> <span class="pl-v">TrackVisible</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c1">=></span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span>  <span class="pl-k">const</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span> ref<span class="pl-kos">,</span> entry <span class="pl-kos">}</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">useInView</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">{</span> <span class="pl-c1">trackVisibility</span>: <span class="pl-c1">true</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">delay</span>: <span class="pl-c1">100</span> <span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span>  <span class="pl-k">return</span> <span class="pl-c1"><</span><span class="pl-ent">div</span> <span class="pl-c1">ref</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-kos">{</span><span class="pl-s1">ref</span><span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-c1">></span><span class="pl-kos">{</span><span class="pl-s1">entry</span><span class="pl-kos">?.</span><span class="pl-c1">isVisible</span><span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-c1"><</span><span class="pl-c1">/</span><span class="pl-ent">div</span><span class="pl-c1">></span><span class="pl-kos">;</span><span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">This is still a very new addition, so check<a href="https://caniuse.com/#feat=intersectionobserver-v2" rel="nofollow">caniuse</a> for current browsersupport. If <code>trackVisibility</code> has been set, and the current browser doesn'tsupport it, a fallback has been added to always report <code>isVisible</code> as <code>true</code>.</p><p dir="auto">It's not added to the TypeScript <code>lib.d.ts</code> file yet, so you will also have toextend the <code>IntersectionObserverEntry</code> with the <code>isVisible</code> boolean.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Recipes</h2><a id="user-content-recipes" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Recipes" href="#recipes"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The <code>IntersectionObserver</code> itself is just a simple but powerful tool. 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">In order to write meaningful tests, the <code>IntersectionObserver</code> needs to bemocked. You can use the included <code>react-intersection-observer/test-utils</code> tohelp with this. It mocks the <code>IntersectionObserver</code>, and includes a few methodsto assist with faking the <code>inView</code> state. When setting the <code>isIntersecting</code>value you can pass either a <code>boolean</code> value or a threshold between 0 and 1. Itwill emulate the real IntersectionObserver, allowing you to validate that yourcomponents are behaving as expected.</p><table><thead><tr><th>Method</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><code>mockAllIsIntersecting(isIntersecting)</code></td><td>Set <code>isIntersecting</code> on all current Intersection Observer instances. The value of <code>isIntersecting</code> should be either a <code>boolean</code> or a threshold between 0 and 1.</td></tr><tr><td><code>mockIsIntersecting(element, isIntersecting)</code></td><td>Set <code>isIntersecting</code> for the Intersection Observer of a specific <code>element</code>. The value of <code>isIntersecting</code> should be either a <code>boolean</code> or a threshold between 0 and 1.</td></tr><tr><td><code>intersectionMockInstance(element)</code></td><td>Call the <code>intersectionMockInstance</code> method with an element, to get the (mocked) <code>IntersectionObserver</code> instance. You can use this to spy on the <code>observe</code> and<code>unobserve</code> methods.</td></tr><tr><td><code>setupIntersectionMocking(mockFn)</code></td><td>Mock the <code>IntersectionObserver</code>, so we can interact with them in tests - Should be called in <code>beforeEach</code>. (<strong>Done automatically in Jest environment</strong>)</td></tr><tr><td><code>resetIntersectionMocking()</code></td><td>Reset the mocks on <code>IntersectionObserver</code> - Should be called in <code>afterEach</code>. (<strong>Done automatically in Jest environment</strong>)</td></tr></tbody></table><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Testing
